text: 3d printing is increasingly being
mentioned on the news and in the media
as a technology for the future some
people are saying that 3d printers will
become as commonplace as printers and
scanners are now people seem to be
getting really excited about it so well
and why might we use a 3d printer and
how does it work well let's take an
example let's imagine you're at home and
to go to do a wash you open up the
washing machine door and the handle
comes off now to replace that part at
the moment which is essentially a
plastic part you'd probably have to call
a repairman he would go to a
distribution center and he'd pick up a
replacement part for you and that part
itself would have been designed on a
computer and it would have been
injection molded probably somewhere like
China where the labor is cheap and then
it would have been shipped on a massive
containership 5,000 miles around the
world to get to that distribution center
to get picked out to get fitted onto
your washing machine and if you think
about it that is mad that piece of
plastic has been transported thousands
of miles you know the amount of energy
that it takes a loan to do that is crazy
and what's exciting about 3d printing is
you have the opportunity to make that
locally so you could download that
original CAD file and create something
much closer to home either fit it
yourself or have it fitted by the
repairman and what's really exciting
about that is you would then have the
opportunity to change that design so if
you had ideas about improving it
reducing material may be putting finger
grips on it you could get onto something
like Google Sketchup or some simple CAD
packages and you could change that
design and anybody could do it and it
really democratizes design and it gets
quite exciting because if you have an
improved design and maybe you upload it
to the manufacturers website and people
start using that there's the potential
that you'd get paid for it so really
exciting opportunity it's also a very
good technology for trying out ideas so
it's used a lot in Formula One and in
aerospace and you know for trying our
ideas very quickly and simply so I had
an idea for a gramophone and
flies up your mobile phone your iphones
be here and you knew we were going to
try that out how to make something
physical so I design something very
quickly in CAD based on a gramophone I
have it here and have this 3d printed so
this is a stereo lithography part and
let me just demonstrate it so the idea
is that you have your iphone you play a
piece of music and then it'll be loud
that's before there we go and this is
made by stereo lithography so this is
lighter ultraviolet light fires at
liquid which cures where the light hits
it so that's how I've made this part
there are two other conventional current
techniques one's called a fused
deposition modeling FDM which is a bit
like a molten little tiny layer a tube
of molten liquid being squirted out and
you build up a part in that way the
final third method is SLS which is
selective laser sintering and that is
using laser fire a pounder to fuse the
powder together and that actually can be
used in powdered metal and that's the
kind of thing that formula one makes so
it really actually is a technology for
the future could be used to do all kinds
of interesting things even the
University of Loughborough are using
cement pipes cement to create houses
very precise houses in 3d printing so
